Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Smart Optical Sensing Patch for Early Detection of Pressure Ulcers
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to alleviate the pain and suffering to patients and the cost to the healthcare system caused by pressure ulcers, or more commonly known as bedsores. Costs associated with treating pressure ulcers have increased significantly in recent decades. Individuals with a pressure ulcer are also at an increased risk of developing an infection at the site of the wound. Notably, hospital-acquired advanced ulcers are reportable to healthcare agencies and thus non-reimbursable, leaving clinical entities absorbing all treatment and legal costs, in addition to a decrease of their healthcare quality ratings.

This I-Corps project will evaluate the commercial viability of a disposable, adhesive sensor that provides nurses with actionable data about the status of their patients' skin, thus eliminating the need for constant visual inspection. The device uses optical sensing technology to monitor structural and functional changes that occur both superficially and under a patient's skin to detect the earliest signs of a pressure ulcer before they become visible to the human eye. In addition to exploring marketability, this project will collect valuable information that will guide potential product development in preparation to clinical validation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcome:

In this project, our team from the Optical Bioimaging Laboratory at the University of Houston explored the customer landscape for a smart patch designed to detect pressure ulcers at their earliest stage.

We joined the I-Corps Winter Cohort (Atlanta) in January ?18, and during the 7-week program we conducted 109 customer discovery interviews, of which 101 were in person, 2 via Skype, and 6 over the phone. We visited the two largest wound-care conferences in the U.S while visiting key stakeholders in three states. After the cohort ended, we continued our customer discover activities focusing on exploring questions around clinical evidence and pricing strategies in order to market our technology. We also investigated manufacturing costs by visiting a trade show in Japan.

The customer discovery process allowed us to generate granular needs and priorities maps of the decision-making unit (DMU), which for our technology has been identified as the Value Assessment Committee that every large hospital has. We generated three value propositions, each one focused on a particular segment of the DMU, i.e. the champion, the influencer and the payer.

Through this project, we have learned about all stakeholders involved in the detection and management of pressure ulcers and the process of adopting and purchasing all sort of devices and products related to this condition, which will be critical to the pursuit of commercialization opportunities for our proposed technology.

Intellectual Merit:

A pressure ulcer (PU) is a damage to the skin and underlying tissues (fat, muscle) caused by prolonged pressure that develops in areas with bone prominences (sacrum, heels, neck, shoulders). To minimize the risk of development of a PU development in patients at risk, i.e., bed-bound patients, current guidelines recommend nurses to conduct a skin assessment and body repositioning every two hours. This method has three key drawbacks; 1) the inter/intra rater reliability of the visual assessment may vary a function of nurses? training and experience; 2) visual inspections require one or more nurses to prioritize their time amid busy schedules; and 3) inspections require movement of the patient, which can be uncomfortable and, in some cases, dangerous. In this project, we propose a solution that eliminates the need for nurses to perform periodic visual assessments. Our technology consists of a disposable, adhesive optical sensor that performs a skin assessment in real time. Additionally, it monitor structural and functional tissue alterations induced by pressure and shear to detect the earliest signs of PUs before they become visible to the human eye. To the best of our knowledge, no other technology can provide real-time tissue monitoring of an impending pressure injury.

The knowledge generated thus far has informed us on some key design characteristics necessary for commercial success, including the need for our device to be flexible, body conforming, and disposable. We have also identified a device form-factor that nurses are most comfortable interacting with, therefore reducing the burden for training.

Broader Impacts:

Currently there are 2.5 million pressure injuries or pressure ulcers (PUs) that occur every year. In addition to the pain and suffering caused by PUs, it is estimated that the cost for treatment can be staggering, with a single PU event ranging from $20,000 to more than $150,000. Worse, hospital-acquired advanced PUs (stage 3 or 4, out of a 4-level severity scale) are reportable to healthcare agencies and thus non-reimbursable, leaving clinical entities absorbing all treatment and legal costs, in addition to a decrease of their healthcare quality ratings. Our proposed sensor aims at reducing the prevalence from 3% to 0.1%, corresponds to a saving of more than $1,000 per admitted patient.

Aside from the societal impact of our solution, this project has exposed the Entrepreneurial Lead to a wide range of activities that have helped him excel in the startup ecosystem, thus paving the way to the commercialization of this technology.
